fields.description:
I have noticed as I am trying to "sell" using atlassian to my company (which has a lot of older developers) they can't see from sourcetree which branch is checked out.

Currently it is merely bolded, but it would be nice to be able to change it so its more noticeable such as put a *simple* icon next to it or change the background color or something to make it more obvious.
fields.summary: Make checked out branch more noticeable

fields.description: When working with multiple repositories, all of the windows look basically the same. Especially when a push to Master results in a Production deploy, one needs to be particularly careful not to commit and push to the wrong repository. Obviously, you can look at the repository name, but it would be great to set a window background color, or some sort of prominent banner on a per-repo basis. That way, the repo for my iOS app can look normal and the repo for the server, which immediately goes to production could be red and foreboding.
fields.summary: Color background or prominent indication of repository

fields.description:
In the app store version of SourceTree there was a feature that all the submodules in GUI's submodule section would have their HEAD commit shown in brackets right in front of the name. This feature is missing from the most recent versions of sourcetree.

Please bring this back. Thanks.
fields.summary: Bring back the submodule head commit info

fields.description: After I click on "Remote" button, application crashes before I manage to input Bitbucket credentials.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes after opening "Remote" tab

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*

1) Create a branch with a long name like "create-a-new-branch-to-make-it-clear-for-something-somewhere-someone-something-func"
2) Checkout master branch
3) Merge the long name branch to master
4) Delete the long name branch

Workaround: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/304204/git-log-failed-with-code-128-fatal-bad-revision-branchname
fields.summary: Deleting a branch causes popup with error message

fields.description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*
1. Make some changes on a file on a local copy of a repo. (For example, a line on a text file)
2. Pull changes from the remote repo. As there is an uncommitted changes, the pull will fail
3. Stash the uncommited file change.
4. Try pulling changes from the remote repo again.
5. Apply the changes which was stashed in previous steps.
6. When a merge conflict occurs, right click to resolve the conflict, there a choice between 'Resolve Using 'Theirs' and 'Resolve Using 'Mines' 
7. The option 'Resolve Using Theirs' somehow uses changes from the local copy, while 'Resolve Using Mine' somehow uses changes from commit copy which is pulled from the server.
fields.summary: When there's a merge conflict trying to apply stashed changes, there's confusion in wording for Resolve Conflict

fields.description: Would be nice to easily see files in a more historic view
fields.summary: Add Sort by "last updated"

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*
1) Have 2 repos hosted on Bitbucket. (Project A and Project B). Project B is a submodule of A.
2) Open Project A on Sourcetree, Checkout an old commit which have changes on the submodule (Project B)
3) An authentication window will appear, showing the issue

A. https:// is doubled
B. the user name is actually specified in the URL
fields.summary: Error when checking out an old commit on a repo with submodules

fields.description:
The following behavior:

* A repository no longer updates its status icons in the list view, and Cmd+R doesn't seem to do anything.

* Double-click on the repository to open it and hit Cmd+R in that view. 

* Close it and return to the list view. Hitting Cmd+R would now cause the expected status icons to appear on that repository.

Unfortunately, this is not a fix as it defeats the purpose of the icons.
fields.summary: "File changes" status icon doesn't show up on local repositories when expected

fields.description:
Occasionally the ST client becomes confused as to whether any files have been modified. It will show that files have indeed been modified, but these files will not show up in the pending files list so that they can be staged. Refreshing the view does not solve the problem, but closing the repository window and then opening a new one in the same git repository does solve the problem.
This particular incident was after visiting previous commits in the master branch in order to locate the commit that caused a bug.
fields.summary: Client does not show modified files

fields.description:
See screen shot.

my.atlassian.com, and id.atlassian.com will allow you to have quote, and double quote characters for your password, but ST cannot seem to parse these properly.
fields.summary: Sourcetree cannot parse certain characters in the password field for registration.

fields.description:
The alternative text of the "push commits" button is wrong.
CURRENT: Push comics zu Remote
CORRECT: Push commits zu Remote
fields.summary: German translation for "push commits" button is wrong.

fields.description:
When amending a commit, the commit preview only shows the new changes that will be added to the original commit, rather than showing a preview of the entire new commit (ie, original commit plus new staged changes). Seeing a preview of the entire new commit would make it easier to review that the changes being added are correct.

Thanks!
fields.summary: show entire new commit when amending commit

fields.description:
When resolving a conflict in a local git repository using an External Tool after quitting the tool the modified file is sometimes not noticed by SourceTree and the file is still marked as conflicting. To resolve the conflict on average 3 times before the modified file is noticed and the conflict resolved.
Tried FileMerge and P4Merge as external tools.
Using El Capitan (10.11.1 (15B42)) and the latest versions of SourceTree (2.0.5.5), P4Merge (P4Merge/MACOSX107X86_64/2015.1/1233444) and FileMerge (2.8 (3005))
fields.summary: Resolving conflicts using External Tool on El Capitan fails

fields.description:
On some occasions, when a branch is rebased onto another (A into B), the GUI doesn't reflect the correct tree structure, and the rebased branch (A) appears as having no parent at all.

Atttempting to perform a rebase again doesn't do anything, and attempting to rebase another branch C into A doesn't do anything also. In both cases no feedback is given to the user whatsoever (no popup, no command history).

Doing a `git log --graph --oneline --decorate` on the repo reveals that the initial rebase was successful, so this is some bug in SourceTree.

I've attached some screenshots regarding an actual case that occurred to me:
I rebased branch `sprint-9/enhancement/add-nullability-and-generics` onto `master`, but the tree is messed up in the GUI (the branch appears as being an "orphan").

Thanks for the great product!
fields.summary: Rebased branch doesn't appear under correct parent commit

fields.description:
A summary of line count changes described in the currently-viewed file should be displayed above the lower right panel when perusing the modified hunks (e.g., “227 lines added, 67 removed”). This information tells the user about what he's looking at.

This is a regression in SourceTree > 1.8.1. This information used to be presented, and is now sorely missed. See attached screen shots.
fields.summary: Diff summary is missing from hunk overview

fields.description: It would be nice to be able to have multiple guides when committing e.g. 50 and 80, for the title and the message of the commit.
fields.summary: Allow multiple column guides in the commit window

fields.description:
Apply stash dialog

WRONG: "Nach Andwenden löschen"
CORRECT: "Nach Anwenden löschen"
fields.summary: wrong Translation 'german'

fields.description:
Git 2.5 come with a new command worktree:
https://git-scm.com/docs/git-worktree

You can use it to manage multiple working trees attached to the same repository.
It is very useful when working on large project with multiple working branches.
Hope GitUp can support this wonderful new feature.

There are some discussion on other git client libraries introducing worktree support:
* https://github.com/github/hub/pull/970
* https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-143404
fields.summary: Add git 2.5 `worktree` command support

fields.description:
See attached screenshot.

If you want to select the text in the view, and the intended selection range exceeds the view's bounds, the view should scroll when the mouse exits the view (e.g. on the top in the case) or, when the selection range is extended, when using keyboard only control.
fields.summary: Unable to extend selection and have the view scroll in the diff view.

fields.description:
For complex graphs, the rule to draw the lines might be improved, to avoid stair like graphs.

Please take a look at the attached window capture: the top inclined lines are just fine, but the bottom ones look like stairs.

Painted with red is the expected path for the outer line. Inner lines can be simplified similarly.
fields.summary: Simplify stair like graphs

fields.description:
Under OS X 10.11, SourceTree has become unusable. 2.0.5.5 is an improvement over 2.0.5.3 in that the application opens, at least after wiping pref's and the 'Application Support/Sourcetree' folder, but crashes or hangs when trying to open existing git repositories.

When specifying a custom git (macport>git v2.6.1) which works by cli, the app complains that the git is in a nonstandard location and returns to the system git.

At the moment the app is completely unusable and I am forced to use the git cli and/or xcode.

The behavior is 100% repeatable on El Capitan (app v2.0.5.3 works under Yosemite).
fields.summary: SourceTree 2.0.5.5 on OS X 10.11 unable to scan repositories

fields.description: i have many local branches. if i want to push a branch to a remote repo it would be great to have the possibility to filter the shown branches. So i can select the needed branch faster.
fields.summary: Filter/Search field in push dialog to limit shown branches

fields.description:
To replicate:

1. Right click a subtree
2. Select "Edit subtree details..."
3. In "Branch / Commit:" the "master" branch is always the default, even if a different branch has previously been selected.

This can lead to accidentally reverting to the original branch. 

Expected behaviour:

1. Right click a subtree
2. Select "Edit subtree details..."
3. In "Branch / Commit:" the used branch should be selected by default.
fields.summary: Edit subtrees selects the incorrect branch when a specific branch has previously been chosen

fields.description:
When I click on "push" I get a box with all my branches ticked. Then I have to unselect all the branches I don't need to and select the one I am working on. And if I forget or don't see it, I end up pushing branches I didn't mean to.

Who ever pushes several branches at once? Normally you push the active branch. In the unlikely case you want to push all branches at once, there is a tickbox for that.

Thanks.
fields.summary: SourceTree: tick active branch by default when pushing. Not ALL branches

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Install Source Tree 2.0.5.5 dmg
# Run the app
# App crashes on startup

Logs attached
fields.summary: Source Tree 2.0.5.5 crashes on startup in OS X 10.11

fields.description:
When viewing an existing commit, the user should be able to sort the file list according to modification state (added, modified, removed, etc.) by clicking on a corresponding table view header. In recent versions of SourceTree, this capability no longer exists.

An attached screen shot shows the file view; the "Filename" column subsumes the status icon which used to be sortable disjointly.

This is a regression in SourceTree >= 1.8.1; the behaviour used to exist (see other attached screen shot).
fields.summary: Allow sorting by modification status in file view

fields.description:
In order to visit a particular commit described by its SHA-1 hash, the user must click on the “Jump to:” pop-up menu in the upper right of the window, then choose the “Commit…” entry from the menu.

This works, but is cumbersome. Visiting a particular commit is a fundamental operation in Git, and thus better accessibility is warranted.

A main menu command (such as “Jump To Commit…”, added to the “Repository” menu) would afford more discoverability; further, a key shortcut (such as Cmd-Shift-J) would enhance its accessibility.
fields.summary: “Jump to Commit” needs a menu command

fields.description:
Clicking twice in succession in file list column header (such as to toggle the sort order twice quickly) has the side effect of also opening the selected file(s) in the list below.

In the attached example, double-clicking on the "Path" column header causes BusinessSelectionViewController.m to be opened in Xcode.

Double-click handling in the table view is evidently wrong; only double-clicks on a selected table row should have such an effect.
fields.summary: Double-clicking in file list column header opens the currently-selected file(s)

fields.description: Currently PNG, JPEG etc images show previews in SourceTree, but SVG images aren't previewed (all that's shown is their XML source)
fields.summary: Preview SVG images

fields.description:
When doing a git flow "Finish Feature" action, the branch is only deleted locally. When the branch was pushed to {{origin}}, it stays there and needs to be deleted manually afterwards. Git Flow can be called with an {{-F}} flag which also removes the branch from the remote. It would help, if SourceTree would expose this action as a checkbox.

http://stackoverflow.com/a/11152136/354018
fields.summary: Git Flow - Delete Remote Branch

fields.description:
We've recently imaged 5 identical OSX Yasomite macbooks with sourcetree on them.

They're all showing identical symptoms that it seems randomly after a period of time or restarting, the bookmark manager displays every repo as missing and you need to relink it.

The folders are not moving and nothings changing, and once you relink it, it works again for a period of time.

Might be worth noting that the users are not admins or in the sudoers file.
fields.summary: Missing or Deleted Repository on restart

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Get a new Mac OS X 10.10
2. Upgrade to OS X 10.11 through App Store
3. Install Source Tree for Mac 2.0.5.3 using the official dmg file downloaded from the web.
4. Launch Source Tree.
5. Source Tree crashes before showing any UI.
fields.summary: Crashes on Startup (OS X 10.11)

fields.description: I attempted to install the SourceTree v2.0.5.3 bugfix update on both OS X 10.10.5 and OS X 10.11 systems without success.  I used the SourceTree > Check for Updates menu item and the updater downloads the file to 44.5/44.6MB, freezes for several seconds, and then provides an error message (shown in attached image).
fields.summary: Unable to update to SourceTree v2.0.5.3 on OS X

fields.description:
Provide the facility for backing up and restoring actions defined under Custom Actions.

It is very tedious to have to manually enter every custom action when moving between installations.

The ability to maintain a shared set of Custom Actions would also help in this capacity.
fields.summary: Custom Actions Recovery

fields.description: SourceTree is waiting indefinately while pushing or pulling. The progressbar just sits there, going from left to right, forever.
fields.summary: Can't pull or push

fields.description:
Note: This affects 2.0.5.3 as well. (It is not yet available in the "Affects Version/s" dropdown list)

For some users, when they open up SourceTree in El Capitan, it freezes (but does not crash). 

If user performs a right click on the SourceTree app at the dock, user will find that there's another window called "Authenticate" behind the scene, but no one will be able to reach to that window:

!sourcetreefreeze.png|thumbnail! 

The only known workaround is to wipe off SourceTree's preferences, and then perform a backup:

* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/SOURCETREEKB/Wiping+SourceTree+Preferences

SourceTree will then run smoothly.
fields.summary: SourceTree freezes during startup in OS 10.11 (El Capitan)

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

#1 Open up Preference > Diff,
#2 In the diff section, fill this up:

{code}
Diff command: osascript
Arguments: -e 'tell app "Finder" to display dialog "Hello World"'
{code}

#3 Open external diff of a file.

#4a If it is a Git repository, it will work: a "Hello World" message should immediately be triggered in Finder.
#4b If it is a Hg repository, it will not work.

------

It also seems that  $LOCAL $REMOTE are the only arguments passed to the external diff command.

An example is to use MacVim (mvim) in diff mode: arguments -f -d are used to invoke Vimdiff without forking a new process. However, arguments are just ignored, and MacVim are invoked with two empty buffers named $REMOTE and $LOCAL.
fields.summary: In a HG repository, custom external diff/merge arguments are not passed

fields.description:
After installing/upgrading to Bitbucket server 4.0.2 I am no longer able to Clone in SourceTree.

Steps to Duplicate:
# Launch Sourcetree
# On the Repository Browser click on remote and you will see a list of repositories on the Bitbucket server
# Click clone
# Note that there is a message that says "This is not a valid source path / URL" and the URL looks like: {{http://cdrummond@localhost/stash///git/TEST/test.git}}
# Note that the Source URL has multiple problems:
# # The port is missing.  I connect to Stash on port 7990 and the port is not there
# # The /scm is missing.  In its place is just //
# # There is an invalid /git in the URL
# # The Project is displayed in all uppercase letters

You can also reproduce this by clicking on the Clone in SourceTree button that displays in Bitbucket Server on the repository clone page. In this case the URL is still malformed but it looks different, from the looks of the Source URL (which can not be edited) everything seems correct but you still get the "This is not a valid source path / URL" messager and you can not click the clone button.
fields.summary: Unable to clone from Bitbucket Server 4.0.2

fields.description:
SourceTree crashes on startup apparently while trying to reopen previously open windows.
App is functional under OS X 10.10.5 and fails after upgrade to El Capitan.
Crash occurs with every attempt to start.
fields.summary: Sourcetree 2.0.5.3 crashes on startup in OS X 10.11

fields.description:
Sourcetree offers the option of stashing your changes before pulling new changes, but if the Stash part of the tree is closed (as it initially is) you may not notice you have to go there. For new users, it would be better if the stash is auto-opened if it was empty, and a new stash is added.

Ideally, the stash entry in the tree, when closed, would show a badge/counter showing how many stashes are in the collapsed tree, which would also give some feedback 'where the stash went'.
fields.summary: The stash in the sidetree should auto-open when adding the first stash

fields.description:
Currently if the user decides to do an interactive rebase, the UI breaks and the user is presented with 'noop'.

Rather SourceTree should, at minimum, use a real error message, for example 

  'this tree has already been merged. Rebasing would change what's already been pushed upstream. if you'd like to rebase anyway, right click a commit and choose 'rebase children interactively' 


Or some thing else - anything would be better than no-op.
fields.summary: Better error message than 'noop' when trying to rebase already pushed tree

fields.description:
While trying to install the command line tools i get an error dialog (see screenshot).
My system.log shows:
{code}Oct  5 09:49:16 core smd[959]: App "com.torusknot.SourceTreeNotMAS" did not pass helper check "com.atlassian.SourceTreePrivilegedHelper2".
Oct  5 09:49:16 core SourceTree[1577]: Failed to install privileged helper: Error Domain=CFErrorDomainLaunchd Code=4 "(null)"
{code}
fields.summary: Cannot install command line tools

fields.description:
I use a lot of technical terms in my commit texts.
SourceTree's textview autocorrects things in a bad bad way.

When I type "json" then two seconds later SourceTree replaces it with "son".
When I type "serialize" then it becomes "serialise".
When I type "swifty" it becomes "swift".

I have made several commits where a message that used the right terms got autocorrect just the moment that I hit commit. I write using 10 fingers, so I'm writing fast. It is really annoying to get autocorrect, when it's wrong.

Please make an option to disable autocorrect in the commit message textview.

Perhaps make a red underline, below the words that may be typed incorrect.
fields.summary: Disable autocorrect in the commit-textview

fields.description:
Logs are not very helpful to get some details:

04.10.15 17:19:26,708 smd[327]: App "com.torusknot.SourceTreeNotMAS" did not pass helper check "com.atlassian.SourceTreePrivilegedHelper2".
04.10.15 17:19:26,708 SourceTree[7809]: Failed to install privileged helper: Error Domain=CFErrorDomainLaunchd Code=4 "(null)"
fields.summary: Can't install Command Line Tools on El Capitan

fields.description:
The commit message window could display hints to help developers follow best practices like the following:

- Subject line: 50 chars or less
- Empty line between subject and body
- Wrap body at 72 chars

Optional:
- Add a setting to enforce these best practices

The window could display a vertical line at 50/72 chars respectively. Additionally, it could automatically add a blank line after the subject line and/or offer auto-wrap for body text.

Inspired by: http://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/
fields.summary: Commit Message Window Improvements

fields.description:
Prior to Mac OS X 10.11, we could use the *git-lfs* extension with SourceTree by simply creating a symbolic link between /usr/local/bin/git-lfs => /usr/bin/git-lfs. But with Mac OS X 10.11, Apple introduced a new "rootless" mode where /usr/bin is restricted and cannot be written into, even with _sudo_. As per an answer from stackoverflow ([copying-file-under-root-got-failed-in-os-x-el-capitan|http://stackoverflow.com/questions/32590053/copying-file-under-root-got-failed-in-os-x-el-capitan-10-11/32590885#32590885]), this cannot be _easily_ disabled.

So the main issue here (IMHO) is SourceTree not having */usr/local/bin* in its PATH. Is this hard to fix?
fields.summary: Cannot use Git Extensions (like git-lfs) on Mac OS X 10.11

fields.description:
When a repository is opened in SourceTree, Open in Terminal and Open in Finder toolbar buttons are available - which are very useful.

Often I find myself having to opening a repository to get to these Open Terminal/Finder buttons.

It would be very helpful if these 2 functions were also available when right-clicking a repository on the initial screen that lists all of the repositories.
fields.summary: Add Open in Terminal menu item when right clicking a repository

fields.description:
Installing command line tools from SourceTree menu fails on OS X 10.11

------------------

(UPDATED) Possible workaround:

Run this command in the terminal:

{code}alias stree='/Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/stree'{code}

Right after running this command, the command tool should work. Users can use it by just typing {{stree}} in the terminal and see if it opens up SourceTree. Or to be more specific: {{stree /path/to/repo}} to see if it opens up a repository.
fields.summary: Sourcetree fails to install command line tools on El Capitan (Mac OS X 10.11)

fields.description:
When resetting a local branch to a commit futther than pulled, the pull counter does not update (say there are 4 commits that needs to be pulled, and then you reset to that).
It works on windows. (by my experince).
fields.summary: hard reset does not update pull count

fields.description: When trying to authenticate, login error pops up. This only happens when two factor authentication is activated.
fields.summary: Two Factor Breaks Source Tree Login

fields.description: On Retina displays, icons DO NOT scale properly for repos cloned from the BitBucket Cloud website, but they DO scale properly for repos created on local machine and then synced to BB Cloud.
fields.summary: Repository icons don't render properly on HiDPI displays

fields.description: If a branch is named, for example, hotfix/bar and hotFix/bar (capital 'F' in 'Fix') in a git repository. However, SourceTree views these branches as the same and pushes changes to the wrong branch. Also, checking out the branch from that particular repository changes the name of the branch and pushes the wrong name.
fields.summary: Issue with case sensitive branches

fields.description:
Steps to recreate:

1. Have a few commits with no branches on the latest commit.
2. Have 3 or more branches
3. Rebase 2 branches successfully to the latest commit and push to the remote branches
Try to rebase the 3rd branch to the latest commit and rather than getting a popup box to confirm the rebase, nothing happens.

This can happen on all commits, not only the latest commit.
fields.summary: SourceTree only allows specifically two local branches to be on a commit via rebase.

fields.description:
If user clones via Hosted Repositories in SourceTree, the URL for the repository won't appear correct:

!bbserver.JPG|thumbnail!

Instead of it being a "https://localhost:7990", it appears as "https://localhost///git".

Cloning directly through Bitbucket Server works fine:

!bbserver2.JPG|thumbnail!


*Work Around*
Manually editing the URL to remove the extra "/" allows the uRL to be correctly identified as a git URL and it can the be cloned.
fields.summary: Cloning Bitbucket Server 4.0 repositories via Hosted Repositories is not possible due to error in the URL

fields.description: Will be nice if I got ability to open repository by keys: Cmd + Down arrow
fields.summary: Ability to open repository by keys

fields.description:
when trying to pull from remote, i get the gitlab error message "{{GitLab: The project you were looking for could not be found.}}":
!Screen Shot 2015-09-25 at 11.48.19.png|thumbnail!

gitlab logfiles show, that Sourcetree is using the wrong SSH Key.

via shell {{ssh git@gitlab}} is using the correct key as specified in {{~/.ssh/config}}.
Gitlab is then recognizing me as "me". {{git pull}} via shell also works correctly.

it took me forever to get my {{~/.ssh/config}} right because of OS X's weird ssh stuff so that at least CLI ssh and git work the right way. (see attached ssh_config)
fields.summary: SSH Config is not (always) used.

fields.description:
A customer said:

I'm using Mac OS X 10.10.3 with SourceTree 2.0.5.2.  It does not appear that remotes are being polled consistently forcing me to have to refresh remotes manually.  I have the polling period down to 5 minutes for "default" remotes and I've tried even bringing this down to 1 minute - my Stash server is not getting polled.  If I manually refresh remotes then it shows the status numbers of pulls, etc.  Also, it seems that when I have SourceTree minimized to the dock it also is not polling so sometimes when I bring it to the front by showing it again it will poll sometimes.  We really need to stay alert of changes available from other developers and need polling and notifications to be reliable and frequent.
fields.summary: Not polling remotes

fields.description:
Trying to log into the Hosted Repositories section whereby the username has a space will not work, despite the username is correct in the remote. 

In fact, the error message that appeares says "unsupported URL", which totally does not make sense:

!remote.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Authentication in the Remote Hosted Repositories section cannot have a space in the username, despite the username is correct or not. In fact, the error message that appeared does not make sense.

fields.description:
When you click the "Push" button in the toolbar, the UI shows you local branch name and remote branch name and even lets you edit the remote branch name, sort of suggesting it would be possible to push to any remote branch. 
However, when the push operation is done, the remote branch that was pushed to has exactly the same name as the local branch. SourceTree effectively ignores the remote branch name given in the UI.
fields.summary: Push remote branch name cannot be renamed

fields.description: In tree view, discard a directory in working copy will discard staged changes too. If "discard file" is clicked for a particular directory, it will discard both staged and unstaged changes.
fields.summary: In tree view, discard a directory in working copy will discard staged changes too

fields.description:
Currently the BRANCHES side-bar alpha-sorts non-folder branches (e.g. {{my_branch}}) correctly, and scrambles the sorting for branches with folders (e.g. {{my_topic/my_subbranch}}). It appears the alpha-sorting for non-folders is only correct for the 1st folder element. 2nd and further subsequent folder branch elements have scrambled sorting. 

See attachment for illustration. Also see this crude representation:

1.0/branch
1.2/a_branch
a_branch
b_branch
c_branch
d_folder/my_branch
a_folder/branch <-- THIS IS THE PROBLEM
f_branch
g_folder/a_branch
c_folder/a_branch <-- THIS IS A REPEAT OF THE PROBLEM

Expect that all branches would be inter-sorted according to their names regardless of whether they are folder-type or not.
fields.summary: Sort Mercurial folder-type branches alphabetically

fields.description: Clicking on this action from the context menu on some file from history results in nothing. The same applies to the Log view.
fields.summary: "Open selected version" doesn't work

fields.description:
Occasionally, when bookmark window is out of focus or closed, and then when it was brought back to focus or opened, the buttons seem to go out of sync for a while:

!jumpbuttons.png|thumbnail!

In order to bring the button back to the middle, just simply touch the window again, or move the window a little.
fields.summary: In OSX 10.10, bookmark window buttons may be out of sync.

fields.description: SourceTree is barely running on OSX 10.11
fields.summary: SourceTree to run properly on OSX 10.11

fields.description:
Git repo doesn't seem to auto refresh even with all the auto-refresh options turned on. Cmd+R have to be manually hit everytime to refresh the project even when "Automatically refresh" is enabled in the settings.

Clearing Sourcetree preferences and reinstalling Sourcetree doesn't seem to help.
fields.summary: SourceTree doesn't refresh a local project

fields.description: When trying to convert a local repository into remote repository, the program stuck at "Please wait a moment while we create your repository". Pressing Cancel but doesn't do anything.
fields.summary: Stuck at "Please wait a moment while we create your repository" when trying to convert a local repository into remote repository

fields.description:
I am using Cocoapods 0.38.2 in my project. After updating pods I did commit and push all the changes. The SourceTree shows that my working copy is clear, no changes to commit. 

But when I pull the commits to other computer (at office) I can't build the project.

Back at home the Terminal command git status shows the following:

{noformat}
$ git status
On branch develop
Changes not staged for commit:
	typechange: Pods/MobileAppTracker/MobileAppTracker.framework/MobileAppTracker
{noformat}

It seems the folder structure has changed in the new version of the MobileAppTracker.framework and SourceTree can't handle this properly.

This issue happened two or three times with other versions of SourceTree too.

I've added screenshots of the framework's structure before and after update. It was update from MobileAppTracker.framework iOS v4.5.0 to v4.6.0. You can try it yourself.

I've changed the priority from Major to Critical because indeed I can't completely rely on SourceTree at my work anymore.
fields.summary: SourceTree does not commit changes properly sometimes

fields.description:
It would be great if in the GUI we have the choice to make a "blank" branch.

In the "Commit" select list we would have another choice like : "None" or "Orphan" or "Blank"

The action made will be the equivalent to these two commands :
git checkout --orphan NEWBRANCH
git rm -rf .

This option should be available according to the git version since git version 1.7.2 or higher is required in order for the --orphan option to be supported.
fields.summary: Add possibility to make blank branch in the new branch GUI

fields.description: Currently it's possible to select branch in log by selecting "All branches", "Current branch" and specific branch in dropdown. It would be great to have ability to paste it from clipboard or enter from keyboard (standard os x autocomplete is not useful in this case).
fields.summary: Add ability to select branch in Log by entering it from keyboard (or pasting from clipboard)

fields.description:
Either by changing the format they’re stored in to be more accessible, or by explicitly writing a file that other applications can use, like 1Password and iTunes do.
 
What’s the use case? Adding the bookmarks’ repos to Quicksilver’s catalog and making them available when selecting SourceTree in Quicksilver and hitting → or /.

Of course it’s already possible to add them to the catalog as regular folders, but they won’t open in SourceTree by default that way.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Please consider allowing 3rd party apps to access the repos in the browser.

fields.description: See attached screenshot.  Sourcetree appropriately switches branches after you clear the error, so its just a cosmetic thing.
fields.summary: Switching branches without nested git repo's creates error.

fields.description:
During install, Sourcetree creates its own ignores file in ~/.gitignore_global.  However, many users already use a standard ignore file/location at ~/.config/git/ignore.  

Sourcetree should scan for global ignore files during the installation and prompt the user if they would like to use their current ignore file, or add a new one at ~/.gitignore_global.

This would also cut down on spamming the home directory with yet another dotfile.
fields.summary: Sourcetree should detect if a global ignore file already exists before creating its own.

fields.description: It would be nice if we could open commit web pages from Source Tree so we could comment on them.
fields.summary: Open commits from SourceTree in GitHub/Bitbucket

fields.description: If there are multiple files that are changed, when trying to use external diff tools (E.g: Kaleidoscope)(CMD+D), multiple instance of the external tool will be opened. For example. while using Kaleidoscope to compare 100 files that are changed, 100 Kaleidoscope windows will be opened.
fields.summary: Many windows being opened when using external diff tool

fields.description:
In the Repository Browser window, when attempting to add a Remote Hosted Repository account using the SSH protocol option, it insists on a username and password as if I was attempting to use the HTTPS option.

Suggestion: When changing the protocol from HTTPS to SSH, the setup window should remove the username/password fields and ask for just a SSH Passphrase with the option to store the passphrase in the Keychain (off by default please!).  If left empty, it would be for a passphrase-less key.

I already have the SSH keys configured properly and I can clone a repo successfully via command line or in the Local pane using the +New Repository > Clone from URL menu without needing to enter a username/password.
fields.summary: Remote Hosted Account setup with SSH insists on credentials

fields.description:
automated build tools usually generate a new tag after each successful build. these tags are simply named by a prefix followed by a progressive count of the build.

 it is very annoying to see hundreds of sequentially numbered tags lined up, when you are examining the log of a file that gets modified very rarely
 
let's say that you have  a sequence of 50 tags named "DeveloperBuild-xxx" like this:

 "DeveloperBuild-495"  "DeveloperBuild-496"  "DeveloperBuild-497"...  "DeveloperBuild-544"

 Could you enhanche the log window in order to detect the presence of these sequentially numbered tags and  visualize them as a SINGLE visual item labeled
    "DeveloperBuild-495 ... 544" ?

thank you!
fields.summary: in log window Visually "collapse" TAGS having a numeric suffix in their name (for tags generated by automated builds)

fields.description:
i've had to rename milner.JPG to milner.jpg on cmd line (because javascript, don't ask). The renamed files didn't show in in SourceTree, but they did in NetBeans. See screenshot. 
It could result in incomplete commits  and break the application.
fields.summary: milner.JPG -> milner.jpg file move not showing up in source tree

fields.description:
It would be super handy to have separate keyboard commands to commit without pushing, and commit then push.

Or... CMD+Enter would commit using the settings you use as default - whether that be "Push after commit" or not.

CMD+Shift+Enter would then commit as the opposite setting to your default. So I would have "Push after commit" unticked. Then I could use CMD+Enter to commit. And CMD+Shift+Enter would commit then push.
fields.summary: Keyboard command to commit and push

fields.description: A GitHub account with Two-Factor Authentication does not work in SourceTree.  Or if it does, I have no idea how to configure it.
fields.summary: Support GitHub TFA

fields.description:
I have many submodules in a repo.  However, I cannot see them in the sidebar.  The "SHOW" button does not unhide when I mouseover "SUBMODULES".

I suspect misconfiguration on my end, but I want to be sure.

Attached is a screenshot, my `.git/config` file and my `.gitmodules` file.
fields.summary: Cannot show submodules or subtrees

fields.description:
We are used to working with IntelliJ when developing and using CI - and their ui for version control is pretty sweet.
But we are using more and more languages not supported by IntelliJ so for those projects we typically use SourceTree or cli.

One thing that would be nice to do is to be able to do a pull even when you have local changes - without first starting pull and waiting for reply and realizing you have local changes, and then  manually stash, pull, apply stash - which is what everyone on the team typically does.

UI-wise it could be an extra checkbox in the pull dialog that would trigger an automatic 
stash -> pull -> apply -> resolve-conflicts-if-any. 

This could be a time saver as SourceTree can take some time  to show the error output in the pull dialog when local changes are present.

Currently we all have a script in a separate 'tools' repository that basically does this added as a custom action

{code}
cd $REPO
git stash save "$MESSAGE" && git pull --rebase && git stash pop
{code}
fields.summary: When having local changes it would be good to still be able to do a pull
Reformat the order of information in the sidebar for git stashes

fields.description:
My SSH key has a password, like most. Most of my repos use SSH. Sometimes my repos want that password while I'm trying to do something else and I press cancel. Then they try again about 20 more times. It's super annoying. I have to hit cancel over and over. If multiple repositories try to get authenticated at the same time, it multiplies. Maybe normal folks like to save their password to keychain, but to me that defeats the purpose. And to press a cancel button that doesn't actually cancel also defeats the purpose.

So please. Make the cancel button on the SSH password prompt actually cancel the whole operation.
fields.summary: Cancel SSH retries like whoa

fields.description:
I would love the ability tell SourceTree to open the repo I'm looking at on the web, if it's a bitbucket or github repo. It's just as useful as "Create Pull Request". 

Thanks!
fields.summary: Open on Web (github/bitbucket)

fields.description:
When using a screen in portrait mode the available space isn't used very well (i.e. lots of blank space in the sidebar and staging lists). A view option to split the view horizontally instead of vertically would be welcome. E.g. in the "file status" view: staging and sidebar on top, and changes on the bottom.

The "log" view is pretty good but could still benefit from cutting off all the blank space at the bottom of the sidebar.
fields.summary: Portrait screen layout

fields.description: See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25306597/how-to-do-git-cherry-pick-continue-in-sourcetree.
fields.summary: No way to issue "git cherry-pick --continue" in SourceTree

fields.description:
When commit is selected to view in the log, it would be nice if the commit details view would show the complete diff by default.

As it is now, when a commit is first selected, it only shows diffs for the first modified file
fields.summary: Show complete diff by default

fields.description: I frequently pull without first fetching when I'm up to date and without changes (there's no reason to, really). When I do this, though, stale remote branches are not pruned (and there is no checkbox to do so). I believe that many other users expect this behavior from a couple of threads I've come across, could you please add this?
fields.summary: Prune on Pull

fields.description: After writing a commit message, when pressing the "commit" button (lower right side), Source Tree sometimes (quite often) crashes. After restarting, commits are ready to be pushed.
fields.summary: Crashes on commit

fields.description:
Please add a function to create patch with binary blob/base64 support.

http://git-scm.com/docs/git-format-patch

{noformat}--binary
In addition to --full-index,
output a binary diff that can be applied with git-apply.{noformat}
fields.summary: Add binary support for git-format-patch on Sourcetree

fields.description: When I click on "Commit", the search field gets selected by default. I expect that I'd rather type in the commit message and hit enter to commit.
fields.summary: Auto-focus on commit message field on commit

fields.description:
My wish: A button (Icon & text) that activates a dropdown with my custom actions.

Background: I think Custom Actions har hidden to far away i terms of mouse clicks and it would be nice if they were available right along with the rest of the commands.
fields.summary: Custom Actions in Toolbar

fields.description:
Hi,

I work with a npm package (https://github.com/petreboy14/redis-scheduler) that uses another npm package (https://github.com/nlf/precommit-hook) as git precommit hook

When I try to make a commit (simple change, just update README) using Source Tree I got an error. See, "Screenshot 2015-08-13 18.28.07.png". However, when I use command line - all is correct. See, "Screenshot 2015-08-13 18.30.55.png"
fields.summary: Cannot do commit using SourceTree when precommit-hook is used

fields.description: Also, the internal and external diff tools show something quite different - with the external tool being correct. Sometimes it is broken where the line numbers are in a repeat.
fields.summary: Compilers that may have Windows legacy (e.g. Xamarin/C#) might cause Windows line ending issues/bugs.

fields.description:
User can navigate stashes using keyboard, but he has to use mouse/trackpad to move cursor over the stash he is interested in and make "option click" to be able to apply or delete stash.

I propose to add intuitive keyboard shortcuts: "Enter" for "Apply Stash" and "Backspace/Delete" for "Delete Stash". User won't have to leave keyboard to perform any of two actions available for stashes.
fields.summary: Apply stash by pressing "Enter/Return", delete stash by pressing "Backspace/Delete"

fields.description:
Whenever SourceTree is open, I get periodic toast notifications about certain repositories having more commits available for me to pull. These notifications can be about any repository I've bookmarked in ST.

The notifications are incredibly distracting. In the context of the work I'm doing, they're completely unimportant.

There doesn't appear to be any way to disable the notifications. I think having that option would be a most welcome relief.
fields.summary: Ability to turn off toast notifications

fields.description: As a user I want to type in console `stree path/to/project --commit commithash` and have sourse tree launched with opened repository and selected commit `commithash`
fields.summary: Add possibility to open the commit from command line

fields.description:
I think it'd be nice to have the ability to see exactly what Git CLI command is being executed when performing a GUI operation. Sometimes when I check a couple boxes during a merge for example. It'd be great to see the Git command equivalent of what action I'm going to be performing. For example, if I've checked options that equal the {{-no-ff}} option during a merge, it'd be nice to see that explicitly so I don't have to decipher whether the check box options are equivalent or not. It might be a great way for people who are used to CLI Git commands to double-check their operations.

Hope you find this suggestion useful.
fields.summary: Show git command line preview during GUI operation
